item.dc:title: Sequential‐Flow Synthesis of Donepezil: A Green and Sustainable Strategy Featuring Heterogeneous Catalysis and Hydrogenation

item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: Synthesis of Aryl Naphthoquinones and Maleimides via Pd(II)‐Catalyzed Template‐Assisted m−C(sp2)−H Functionalization Reaction
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, Volume 30, Issue 59, October 23, 2024.
item.dc:description:
Pd(II)‐catalyzed template‐assisted m−C(sp2)−H functionalization reaction of arylmethane sulfonates has been reported. The methodology has been found to be compatible with naphthoquinones and various maleimides and thus further generated the desired product in good yields with a very high meta‐selectivity. A plausible reaction mechanism has also been proposed.
Abstract An efficient approach for the synthesis of substituted aryl naphthoquinones via a Pd(II)‐catalyzed template‐assisted m−C(sp2)−H bond functionalization reaction of arylmethane sulfonates have been demonstrated. The method involves usage of less expensive and abundant pharmacologically important scaffold naphthoquinone. A wide range of arylmethane sulfonates were examined and found to be compatible with the protocol. The protocol has also been further extended to the synthesis of various substituted aryl maleimide scaffolds. A plausible reaction mechanism has also been proposed to account for the selective distal m−C(sp2)−H bond functionalization reaction.
item.content:encoded:
Pd(II)-catalyzed template-assisted m−C(sp2)−H functionalization reaction of arylmethane sulfonates has been reported. The methodology has been found to be compatible with naphthoquinones and various maleimides and thus further generated the desired product in good yields with a very high meta-selectivity. A plausible reaction mechanism has also been proposed.


Abstract

An efficient approach for the synthesis of substituted aryl naphthoquinones via a Pd(II)-catalyzed template-assisted m−C(sp2)−H bond functionalization reaction of arylmethane sulfonates have been demonstrated. The method involves usage of less expensive and abundant pharmacologically important scaffold naphthoquinone. A wide range of arylmethane sulfonates were examined and found to be compatible with the protocol. The protocol has also been further extended to the synthesis of various substituted aryl maleimide scaffolds. A plausible reaction mechanism has also been proposed to account for the selective distal m−C(sp2)−H bond functionalization reaction.
item.dc:creator: Ananya Dutta, Masilamani Jeganmohan
item.dc:title: Synthesis of Aryl Naphthoquinones and Maleimides via Pd(II)‐Catalyzed Template‐Assisted m−C(sp2)−H Functionalization Reaction

item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: Organoboron Polymorphs with Different Molecular Packing Modes for Optical Waveguides
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, Volume 30, Issue 59, October 23, 2024.
item.dc:description:
An organoboron compound and its polymorphic crystals with different packing modes are developed. Narrowband photoluminescence spectra with the FWHM of less than 30 nm are obtained in solution, thin film and microcrystals, while TADF and optical waveguide properties are also demonstrated in microcrystals.
Abstract Organoboron compounds offer a new strategy to design optoelectronic materials with high fluorescence efficiency. In this paper, the organoboron compound B‐BNBP with double B←N bridged bipyridine bearing four fluorine atoms as core unit is facilely synthesized and exhibits a narrowband emission spectrum and a high photoluminescence quantum yield (PLQY) of 86.53 % in solution. Its polymorphic crystals were controllable prepared by different solution self‐assembly methods. Two microcrystals possess different molecular packing modes, one‐dimensional microstrips (1D‐MSs) for H‐aggregation and two‐dimensional microdisks (2D‐MDs) for J‐aggregation, owing to abundant intermolecular interactions of four fluorine atoms sticking out conjugated plane. Their structure‐property relationships were investigated by crystallographic analysis and theoretical calculation. Strong emission spectra with the full width at half maximum (FWHM) of less than 30 nm can also be observed in thin film and 2D‐MDs. 1D‐MSs possess thermally activated delayed fluorescence (TADF) property and exhibit superior optical waveguide performance with an optical loss of 0.061 dB/μm. This work enriches the diversity of polymorphic microcrystals and further reveals the structure‐property relationship in organoboron micro/nano‐crystals.
item.content:encoded:
An organoboron compound and its polymorphic crystals with different packing modes are developed. Narrowband photoluminescence spectra with the FWHM of less than 30 nm are obtained in solution, thin film and microcrystals, while TADF and optical waveguide properties are also demonstrated in microcrystals.


Abstract

Organoboron compounds offer a new strategy to design optoelectronic materials with high fluorescence efficiency. In this paper, the organoboron compound B-BNBP with double B←N bridged bipyridine bearing four fluorine atoms as core unit is facilely synthesized and exhibits a narrowband emission spectrum and a high photoluminescence quantum yield (PLQY) of 86.53 % in solution. Its polymorphic crystals were controllable prepared by different solution self-assembly methods. Two microcrystals possess different molecular packing modes, one-dimensional microstrips (1D-MSs) for H-aggregation and two-dimensional microdisks (2D-MDs) for J-aggregation, owing to abundant intermolecular interactions of four fluorine atoms sticking out conjugated plane. Their structure-property relationships were investigated by crystallographic analysis and theoretical calculation. Strong emission spectra with the full width at half maximum (FWHM) of less than 30 nm can also be observed in thin film and 2D-MDs. 1D-MSs possess thermally activated delayed fluorescence (TADF) property and exhibit superior optical waveguide performance with an optical loss of 0.061 dB/μm. This work enriches the diversity of polymorphic microcrystals and further reveals the structure-property relationship in organoboron micro/nano-crystals.
item.dc:creator: Tingting Zhao, Suru A, Yurong Ma, Nan Wang, Fangbin Liu, Zhongmin Su
item.dc:title: Organoboron Polymorphs with Different Molecular Packing Modes for Optical Waveguides

item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: Photoelectrocatalytic [4+2] Annulation for S‐Heterocycle Assembly Enabled by Proton‐Coupled Electron Transfer (PCET)
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, Volume 30, Issue 59, October 23, 2024.
item.dc:description:
The synthesis of isothiochromenes by PCET‐accelerated photoelectrocatalytic intermolecular dehydrogenative [4+2] C−S/C−C annulation was developed. The resource‐economic photoelectrosynthesis obviated transition‐metal catalysts, oxidation reagents, and high reaction temperatures.
Abstract Cross‐dehydrogenative couplings (CDC) present an efficient strategy for the assembly of biorelevant heterocycles, but are thus far largely limited to toxic transition metals and rather harsh reaction conditions. In sharp contrast, we, herein report on a mild photoelectrocatalyzed CDC‐[4+2] annulation enabling the synthesis of functionalized isothiochromenes enabled by a proton‐coupled electron transfer (PCET) strategy. The transformative photoelectrocatalysis obviated toxic transition‐metal, high reaction temperatures, and stoichiometric chemical redox reagents. This approach was characterized by exceedingly mild conditions, ample substrate scope, and a commercially available catalyst. Gram‐scale reactions and a telescoped synthesis route reflected the unique potential in the green synthesis of important S‐heterocycles.
item.content:encoded:
The synthesis of isothiochromenes by PCET-accelerated photoelectrocatalytic intermolecular dehydrogenative [4+2] C−S/C−C annulation was developed. The resource-economic photoelectrosynthesis obviated transition-metal catalysts, oxidation reagents, and high reaction temperatures.


Abstract

Cross-dehydrogenative couplings (CDC) present an efficient strategy for the assembly of biorelevant heterocycles, but are thus far largely limited to toxic transition metals and rather harsh reaction conditions. In sharp contrast, we, herein report on a mild photoelectrocatalyzed CDC-[4+2] annulation enabling the synthesis of functionalized isothiochromenes enabled by a proton-coupled electron transfer (PCET) strategy. The transformative photoelectrocatalysis obviated toxic transition-metal, high reaction temperatures, and stoichiometric chemical redox reagents. This approach was characterized by exceedingly mild conditions, ample substrate scope, and a commercially available catalyst. Gram-scale reactions and a telescoped synthesis route reflected the unique potential in the green synthesis of important S-heterocycles.
item.dc:creator: Yuan‐Yuan Cheng, Jiawei Xu, Zhipeng Lin, Yanjun Li, Lutz Ackermann
item.dc:title: Photoelectrocatalytic [4+2] Annulation for S‐Heterocycle Assembly Enabled by Proton‐Coupled Electron Transfer (PCET)

item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: Adaptation of the BaAl4 Type to Small Cations: The Case of NaGa4
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, Volume 30, Issue 59, October 23, 2024.
item.dc:description:
The crystal structure of NaGa4 presents a branch of the BaAl4 type characterized by an unusually large c/a ratio. This distortion allows the BaAl4 type to accommodate small cations, providing an alternative to the monoclinic distortion observed in the CaGa4 type.
Abstract Single‐phase NaGa4 samples were prepared by annealing stoichiometric element mixtures at 200 °C, 300 °C, and 450 °C in closed tantalum ampoules. No compositional homogeneity range was detected. While single crystals annealed at 200 °C feature a fully ordered crystal structure, a crystal annealed at 300 °C reveals a defect with mutual exchange of Na atoms and Ga2 dumbbells. The structure motif caused by the violation of translational symmetry resembles the CeMg2Si2 type of structure. The NaGa4 structure constitutes a branch of the BaAl4 type distinguished by a notably high c/a ratio (space group I4/mmm; a=4.2261(1) Å, c=11.2633(6) Å, c/a=2.67). This distortion enables the adaption of the BaAl4‐type to small cations, when the further shortening of the apical–apical distance d(Ga–Ga) is not possible any more. Therefore, NaGa4 offers an adaption alternative to the monoclinic distortion observed in CaGa4 and YbGa4. Conductivity measurements validate the metallic behavior anticipated by NMR measurements in earlier studies.
item.content:encoded:
The crystal structure of NaGa4 presents a branch of the BaAl4 type characterized by an unusually large c/a ratio. This distortion allows the BaAl4 type to accommodate small cations, providing an alternative to the monoclinic distortion observed in the CaGa4 type.


Abstract

Single-phase NaGa4 samples were prepared by annealing stoichiometric element mixtures at 200 °C, 300 °C, and 450 °C in closed tantalum ampoules. No compositional homogeneity range was detected. While single crystals annealed at 200 °C feature a fully ordered crystal structure, a crystal annealed at 300 °C reveals a defect with mutual exchange of Na atoms and Ga2 dumbbells. The structure motif caused by the violation of translational symmetry resembles the CeMg2Si2 type of structure. The NaGa4 structure constitutes a branch of the BaAl4 type distinguished by a notably high c/a ratio (space group I4/mmm; a=4.2261(1) Å, c=11.2633(6) Å, c/a=2.67). This distortion enables the adaption of the BaAl4-type to small cations, when the further shortening of the apical–apical distance d(Ga–Ga) is not possible any more. Therefore, NaGa4 offers an adaption alternative to the monoclinic distortion observed in CaGa4 and YbGa4. Conductivity measurements validate the metallic behavior anticipated by NMR measurements in earlier studies.
item.dc:creator: Chia‐Chi Yu, Yurii Prots, Primož Koželj, Frank R. Wagner, Michael Baitinger, Yuri Grin
item.dc:title: Adaptation of the BaAl4 Type to Small Cations: The Case of NaGa4

item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: Unraveling the Source of Self‐Induced Diastereomeric Anisochronism in Chiral Dipeptides
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, Volume 30, Issue 59, October 23, 2024.
item.dc:description:
NMR spectroscopy and computational analysis shed light on the SIDA (Self‐Induced Diastereomeric Anisochronism) phenomenon occurring in non‐racemic mixtures of chiral dipeptide derivatives. Self‐assembly in solution gives rise to diastereomeric homochiral and heterochiral adducts tightly associated, which can be differentiated by proton NMR analysis based on their different chemical shift, due to a different stereochemical arrangement.
Abstract Mastering of analytical methods for accurate quantitative determinations of enantiomeric excess is a crucial aspect in asymmetric catalysis, chiral synthesis, and pharmaceutical applications. In this context, the phenomenon of Self‐Induced Diastereomeric Anisochronism (SIDA) can be exploited in NMR spectroscopy for accurate determinations of enantiomeric composition, without using a chiral auxiliary that could interfere with the spectroscopic investigation. This phenomenon can be particularly useful for improving the quantitative analysis of mixtures with low enantiomeric excesses, where direct integration of signals can be tricky. Here, we describe a novel analysis protocol to correctly determine the enantiomeric composition of scalemic mixtures and investigate the thermodynamic and stereochemical features at the basis of SIDA. Dipeptide derivatives were chosen as substrates for this study, given their central role in drug design. By integrating the experiments with a conformational stochastic search that includes entropic contributions, we provide valuable information on the dimerization thermodynamics, the nature of non‐covalent interactions leading to self‐association, and the differences in the chemical environment responsible for the anisochronism, highlighting the importance of different stereochemical arrangement and tight association for the distinction between homochiral and heterochiral adducts. An important role played by the counterion was pointed out by computational studies.
item.content:encoded:
NMR spectroscopy and computational analysis shed light on the SIDA (Self-Induced Diastereomeric Anisochronism) phenomenon occurring in non-racemic mixtures of chiral dipeptide derivatives. Self-assembly in solution gives rise to diastereomeric homochiral and heterochiral adducts tightly associated, which can be differentiated by proton NMR analysis based on their different chemical shift, due to a different stereochemical arrangement.


Abstract

Mastering of analytical methods for accurate quantitative determinations of enantiomeric excess is a crucial aspect in asymmetric catalysis, chiral synthesis, and pharmaceutical applications. In this context, the phenomenon of Self-Induced Diastereomeric Anisochronism (SIDA) can be exploited in NMR spectroscopy for accurate determinations of enantiomeric composition, without using a chiral auxiliary that could interfere with the spectroscopic investigation. This phenomenon can be particularly useful for improving the quantitative analysis of mixtures with low enantiomeric excesses, where direct integration of signals can be tricky. Here, we describe a novel analysis protocol to correctly determine the enantiomeric composition of scalemic mixtures and investigate the thermodynamic and stereochemical features at the basis of SIDA. Dipeptide derivatives were chosen as substrates for this study, given their central role in drug design. By integrating the experiments with a conformational stochastic search that includes entropic contributions, we provide valuable information on the dimerization thermodynamics, the nature of non-covalent interactions leading to self-association, and the differences in the chemical environment responsible for the anisochronism, highlighting the importance of different stereochemical arrangement and tight association for the distinction between homochiral and heterochiral adducts. An important role played by the counterion was pointed out by computational studies.
item.dc:creator: Fabio Spiaggia, Federica Aiello, Luca Sementa, Jean‐Marc Campagne, Renata Marcia de Figueiredo, Gloria Uccello Barretta, Federica Balzano
item.dc:title: Unraveling the Source of Self‐Induced Diastereomeric Anisochronism in Chiral Dipeptides

item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: Tetrel Bond Affects the Self‐Assembly of Acetylcholine and its Analogues and is an Ancillary Interaction in Protein Binding
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, Volume 30, Issue 59, October 23, 2024.
item.dc:description:
Experimental and theoretical findings show that the C atoms of the −N+(CH3)3 moiety of acetylcholine and some analogues form tetrel bonds that are robust enough to assemble cations into supramolecular infinite chains; similar tetrel bonds are present also in substrate/protein adducts, specifically they act as ancillary interactions in the binding of these −N+(CH3)3 containing compounds to proteins.
Abstract The −N+(CH3)3 residue is present in acetylcholine (ACh) and in many of its analogues which are used as selective ACh agonist or antagonists for human therapy. The X‐ray structures of four ACh derivatives show the presence of short and linear contacts between the C atoms of −N+(CH3)3 groups and lone pair possessing atoms. These contacts can be rationalized as tetrel bonds (TtBs) thanks to their geometric features. Interrogation of the Protein Data Bank suggests that similar −N+−C⋅⋅⋅nucleophile contacts affect the details of the binding of ACh and its derivatives to proteins. Quantum theory of atoms in molecules, noncovalent interaction plot, and natural bond orbital analyses consistently confirm that the −N+−C⋅⋅⋅nucleophile contacts observed in small molecule crystals and in substrate/protein complexes are attractive in nature and can be rationalized as TtBs. TtBs involving methyl groups of the −N+(CH3)3 moiety can be proposed as a new item in the palette of interactions allowing the compounds containing this pharmacophoric unit to bind to their target protein and/or to express their biological/pharmacological properties.
item.content:encoded:
Experimental and theoretical findings show that the C atoms of the −N+(CH3)3 moiety of acetylcholine and some analogues form tetrel bonds that are robust enough to assemble cations into supramolecular infinite chains; similar tetrel bonds are present also in substrate/protein adducts, specifically they act as ancillary interactions in the binding of these −N+(CH3)3 containing compounds to proteins.


Abstract

The −N+(CH3)3 residue is present in acetylcholine (ACh) and in many of its analogues which are used as selective ACh agonist or antagonists for human therapy. The X-ray structures of four ACh derivatives show the presence of short and linear contacts between the C atoms of −N+(CH3)3 groups and lone pair possessing atoms. These contacts can be rationalized as tetrel bonds (TtBs) thanks to their geometric features. Interrogation of the Protein Data Bank suggests that similar −N+−C⋅⋅⋅nucleophile contacts affect the details of the binding of ACh and its derivatives to proteins. Quantum theory of atoms in molecules, noncovalent interaction plot, and natural bond orbital analyses consistently confirm that the −N+−C⋅⋅⋅nucleophile contacts observed in small molecule crystals and in substrate/protein complexes are attractive in nature and can be rationalized as TtBs. TtBs involving methyl groups of the −N+(CH3)3 moiety can be proposed as a new item in the palette of interactions allowing the compounds containing this pharmacophoric unit to bind to their target protein and/or to express their biological/pharmacological properties.

item.dc:title: Tetrel Bond Affects the Self‐Assembly of Acetylcholine and its Analogues and is an Ancillary Interaction in Protein Binding

item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: Front Cover: Sequential‐Flow Synthesis of Donepezil: A Green and Sustainable Strategy Featuring Heterogeneous Catalysis and Hydrogenation (Chem. Eur. J. 59/2024)
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, Volume 30, Issue 59, October 23, 2024.
item.dc:description: An atom‐economical, continuous‐flow synthesis of donepezil, an Alzheimer′s drug, was achieved by using inexpensive and commercially available precursors. This approach highlights the importance of reconfiguring the synthetic route to utilize heterogeneous catalysis in continuous‐flow hydrogenation reactions. The process produced water as the only by‐product. Various obstacles were overcome by effectively eliminating inhibitory factors, leading to the successful realization of a one‐flow synthesis. More information can be found in the Research Article by H. Ishitani, S. Kobayashi and co‐workers (DOI: 10.1002/chem.202402128).

item.title: Cover Feature: Tetrel Bond Affects the Self‐Assembly of Acetylcholine and its Analogues and is an Ancillary Interaction in Protein Binding (Chem. Eur. J. 59/2024)
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, Volume 30, Issue 59, October 23, 2024.
item.dc:description: Experimental and theoretical results consistently indicate that the −CH3 groups of choline as well as of its agonists and antagonists containing the −N+(CH3)3 moiety can form tetrel bonds with a variety of nucleophiles. Importantly, this interaction can also contribute to the binding of these molecules to proteins; it might thus be convenient that chemists and biochemists become as acquainted with the tetrel bonds formed by the −N+(CH3)3 moiety as they are with their daily servings. More information can be found in the Research Article by G. Resnati and co‐workers (DOI: 10.1002/chem.202401824).

item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: Cover Feature: Crystallography Reveals Metal‐Triggered Restructuring of β‐Hairpins (Chem. Eur. J. 59/2024)
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, Volume 30, Issue 59, October 23, 2024.
item.dc:description: β‐Sheet peptides have long been pursued as ligands for bioinorganic chemistry. However, crystal structures of metal complexes with β‐sheet peptides have remained elusive. By using a tryptophan zipper β‐hairpin scaffold (12 amino acids), several histidine residues were incorporated to produce metal‐binding peptides. Two Cu–β‐sheet complexes were characterized by single‐crystal X‐ray crystallography and solution‐phase measurements. The data reveal that Cu binding can trigger unexpected restructuring of the original hairpin structure into hairpin dimers and domain‐swapped dimers, depending on the number and location of the histidine residues. More information can be found in the Research Article by A. I. Nguyen and co‐workers (DOI: 10.1002/chem.202402101).
item.content:encoded: β-Sheet peptides have long been pursued as ligands for bioinorganic chemistry. However, crystal structures of metal complexes with β-sheet peptides have remained elusive. By using a tryptophan zipper β-hairpin scaffold (12 amino acids), several histidine residues were incorporated to produce metal-binding peptides. Two Cu–β-sheet complexes were characterized by single-crystal X-ray crystallography and solution-phase measurements. The data reveal that Cu binding can trigger unexpected restructuring of the original hairpin structure into hairpin dimers and domain-swapped dimers, depending on the number and location of the histidine residues. More information can be found in the Research Article by A. I. Nguyen and co-workers (DOI: 10.1002/chem.202402101).

item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, Volume 30, Issue 59, October 23, 2024.
item.dc:description: The Cover Feature illustrates defects in the NaGa4 structure caused by the mutual exchange of Na atoms and Ga₂ dumbbells. These defects form at elevated temperatures and can be interpreted as the embedding of CeMg2Si2‐type segments into the BaAl4‐type matrix. More information can be found in the Research Article by Y. Grin and co‐workers (DOI: 10.1002/chem.202402457).

Grin and co-workers (DOI: 10.1002/chem.202402457).

item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: Review on Catalytic Meinwald Rearrangement of Epoxides
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, Volume 30, Issue 59, October 23, 2024.
item.dc:description:
This comprehensive review encapsulates the applications of Meinwald rearrangement and the rearranged products as precursors of carbonyl compounds for the further transformations. It is expected that this review can inspire chemists to continuously contribute to this field and further promote the development of Meinwald rearrangement, and provide efficient access to high‐value molecules.
Abstract The past few decades have witnessed tremendous development within epoxides. Among the many known reactions involving epoxide, Meinwald rearrangements represent one of the most important and attractive approaches, which can transform epoxides into versatile carbonyl compounds. Given the high efficiency of this protocol, substantial efforts have been made by researchers by utilizing multiple catalyst systems. This review provides an overview of recent advances in the Meinwald rearrangement (from 2014 onward), along with detailed discussions on mechanistic insights. This review aims to highlight the importance and value of these methodologies, thereby promoting further investigation and application.
item.content:encoded:
This comprehensive review encapsulates the applications of Meinwald rearrangement and the rearranged products as precursors of carbonyl compounds for the further transformations. It is expected that this review can inspire chemists to continuously contribute to this field and further promote the development of Meinwald rearrangement, and provide efficient access to high-value molecules.


Abstract

The past few decades have witnessed tremendous development within epoxides. Among the many known reactions involving epoxide, Meinwald rearrangements represent one of the most important and attractive approaches, which can transform epoxides into versatile carbonyl compounds. Given the high efficiency of this protocol, substantial efforts have been made by researchers by utilizing multiple catalyst systems. This review provides an overview of recent advances in the Meinwald rearrangement (from 2014 onward), along with detailed discussions on mechanistic insights. This review aims to highlight the importance and value of these methodologies, thereby promoting further investigation and application.

item.dc:title: Review on Catalytic Meinwald Rearrangement of Epoxides

item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: Differential Sensing Approach as a Pattern‐based Discrimination for Biological Samples
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A differential sensing strategy offers great potential for biological sample discrimination and diagnostics. Distinctive response patterns were generated for various bacteria, viruses, and biofluids with different disease states using a series of sensor arrays, including colorimetric off‐the‐shelf dyes, surface‐functionalized nanoparticles and fluorophores, graphene oxide, fluorescent reporters, and chemosensors.
Abstract The differential sensing approach uses fingerprint patterning to distinguish uncharacterized biological samples. Inspired by natural sensory systems, an array of cross‐reactive sensors generates unique response fingerprint depending on the samples. Until today, this array system has been developed using various materials, including the library of surface‐charged nanoparticles and chemosensors. Many differential array systems have demonstrated accurate identification of bacterial species, viral subtypes, and cancer cells, as well as distinguishing disease states in blood or urine. This capability is particularly important for distinguishing between normal and abnormal states when specific marker molecules have not yet been identified, providing a powerful diagnostic tool. In this concept, we summarized representative outcomes of differential sensing applications for biological sample discrimination.

Abstract

The differential sensing approach uses fingerprint patterning to distinguish uncharacterized biological samples. Inspired by natural sensory systems, an array of cross-reactive sensors generates unique response fingerprint depending on the samples. Until today, this array system has been developed using various materials, including the library of surface-charged nanoparticles and chemosensors. Many differential array systems have demonstrated accurate identification of bacterial species, viral subtypes, and cancer cells, as well as distinguishing disease states in blood or urine. This capability is particularly important for distinguishing between normal and abnormal states when specific marker molecules have not yet been identified, providing a powerful diagnostic tool. In this concept, we summarized representative outcomes of differential sensing applications for biological sample discrimination.

item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: Photoresponsive Dioxazaborocanes‐Containing Oligomers
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A new synthetic methodology for the preparation of photoresponsive oligomers containing dioxazaborocanes is developed from β‐aminodiols and a bis‐borylated dithienylethene photochromic unit. Their photophysical properties are evaluated, as well as their suitability for the preparation of spin‐coated films whose photomechanical behavior is assessed.
Abstract The synthetic methodology for the preparation of photoresponsive dioxazaborocanes‐containing oligomers is developed. It relies on the transformation of the (diisopropylamino)boryl group (−BH(NiPr2)) into a dioxazaborocane unit in the presence of β‐aminodiols and involves a bis‐borylated dithienylethene photochromic unit. The photophysical properties of the obtained oligomers are evaluated as well as their processability for the preparation of spin‐coated films. The photomechanical behavior of the resulting films is assessed via displacement tracking profile.
item.content:encoded:
A new synthetic methodology for the preparation of photoresponsive oligomers containing dioxazaborocanes is developed from β-aminodiols and a bis-borylated dithienylethene photochromic unit. Their photophysical properties are evaluated, as well as their suitability for the preparation of spin-coated films whose photomechanical behavior is assessed.


Abstract

The synthetic methodology for the preparation of photoresponsive dioxazaborocanes-containing oligomers is developed. It relies on the transformation of the (diisopropylamino)boryl group (−BH(NiPr2)) into a dioxazaborocane unit in the presence of β-aminodiols and involves a bis-borylated dithienylethene photochromic unit. The photophysical properties of the obtained oligomers are evaluated as well as their processability for the preparation of spin-coated films. The photomechanical behavior of the resulting films is assessed via displacement tracking profile.
item.dc:creator: Nour Nour Eddine, Laurine Meslong, Marie Cordier, Ismael Arroyo Diaz, Stéphane Aloïse, Marc Devillard, Gilles Alcaraz
item.dc:title: Photoresponsive Dioxazaborocanes‐Containing Oligomers

item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: Synthesis, Reactivity, and Bonding Analysis of a Tetracoordinated Nickel Carbene
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
The isolation of a four‐coordinate triphosphine nickel carbene complex challenges the generally accepted idea that low coordination numbers are required to stabilize M=C double bonds at late transition metal centers. The isolated compound displays nucleophilic and carbene‐transfer reactivity. Computational analyses shed light on the unexpected role of the third phosphine in stabilizing the Ni=C fragment.
Abstract Nickel carbenes are key reactive intermediates in the catalytic cyclopropanation of olefins and other reactions, but isolated examples are scarce and generally rely on low coordination numbers (≤3) to stabilize the metal−ligand multiple bond. Here we report the isolation and characterization of a stable tetracoordinated nickel carbene bearing a triphosphine pincer ligand. Its nucleophilic character is evidenced by reaction with acids, and it can transfer the carbene fragment to CO to form a ketene. A computational study of the Ni=C chemical bond sheds light on the role of the third phosphine in the pincer framework to the stabilization of the nickel carbene fragment.
item.content:encoded:
The isolation of a four-coordinate triphosphine nickel carbene complex challenges the generally accepted idea that low coordination numbers are required to stabilize M=C double bonds at late transition metal centers. The isolated compound displays nucleophilic and carbene-transfer reactivity. Computational analyses shed light on the unexpected role of the third phosphine in stabilizing the Ni=C fragment.


Abstract

Nickel carbenes are key reactive intermediates in the catalytic cyclopropanation of olefins and other reactions, but isolated examples are scarce and generally rely on low coordination numbers (≤3) to stabilize the metal−ligand multiple bond. Here we report the isolation and characterization of a stable tetracoordinated nickel carbene bearing a triphosphine pincer ligand. Its nucleophilic character is evidenced by reaction with acids, and it can transfer the carbene fragment to CO to form a ketene. A computational study of the Ni=C chemical bond sheds light on the role of the third phosphine in the pincer framework to the stabilization of the nickel carbene fragment.
item.dc:creator: Pablo M. Pérez‐García, María L. G. Sansores‐Paredes, Célia Fonseca Guerra, Pascal Vermeeren, Marc‐Etienne Moret
item.dc:title: Synthesis, Reactivity, and Bonding Analysis of a Tetracoordinated Nickel Carbene

item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: A Computational Study of Reactions with Boric Acid Aimed to Promote the Utilization of Lignin
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
The DFT calculation shows that control of the reaction of boric acid with hydroxide anion and the deprotonation of water clusters catalyzed by sodium cation are crucial to the reaction between lignin and boric acid under the alkaline condition.
Abstract For exploring the reaction between the hydroxyl groups of lignin and boric acid under the alkaline condition, we study three proposed mechanisms for the formation of the anionic borate diester (ABDE) using the salicyl alcohol anion as the model compound by the density functional theory. ABDE has high flame retardancy and is a potentially practical application of lignin. The catalysis of sodium cation is found to enhance the deprotonation of the water cluster. The deprotonated product, hydroxide anion, is essential to the critical step, which is the cleavage of B−O bonds of the boric acid molecule, in reaction mechanisms. The energy profiles of the mechanisms show that the reaction between lignin and boric acid may start from the hydroxymethyl moieties of lignin since it requires less energy for the aforementioned critical step than from the phenol moieties of lignin. Moreover, the hydroxide anions compete with the hydroxymethyl groups in lignin for the formation of B−O bonds by forming tetrahydroxyborate anion (TBA) which requires very high activation energies to further react to the desired product ABDE. The optimal condition is to enhance the catalytic effect of sodium cations and meanwhile to control the formation of TBA.
item.content:encoded:
The DFT calculation shows that control of the reaction of boric acid with hydroxide anion and the deprotonation of water clusters catalyzed by sodium cation are crucial to the reaction between lignin and boric acid under the alkaline condition.


Abstract

For exploring the reaction between the hydroxyl groups of lignin and boric acid under the alkaline condition, we study three proposed mechanisms for the formation of the anionic borate diester (ABDE) using the salicyl alcohol anion as the model compound by the density functional theory. ABDE has high flame retardancy and is a potentially practical application of lignin. The catalysis of sodium cation is found to enhance the deprotonation of the water cluster. The deprotonated product, hydroxide anion, is essential to the critical step, which is the cleavage of B−O bonds of the boric acid molecule, in reaction mechanisms. The energy profiles of the mechanisms show that the reaction between lignin and boric acid may start from the hydroxymethyl moieties of lignin since it requires less energy for the aforementioned critical step than from the phenol moieties of lignin. Moreover, the hydroxide anions compete with the hydroxymethyl groups in lignin for the formation of B−O bonds by forming tetrahydroxyborate anion (TBA) which requires very high activation energies to further react to the desired product ABDE. The optimal condition is to enhance the catalytic effect of sodium cations and meanwhile to control the formation of TBA.
item.dc:creator: Yu‐Chung Wu, Chin‐Hui Yu
item.dc:title: A Computational Study of Reactions with Boric Acid Aimed to Promote the Utilization of Lignin

item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: Room‐Temperature Quantum Coherence of Reversible Photo‐Generated Radical and its Film
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
The reversible photogenerated radicals 2,4,6‐Tri(4‐pyridyl)‐1,3,5‐triazine (tpt) show a temperature‐independent quantum coherence with Tm=1.1 μs at 20–300 K and the Tm of tpt‐film increased by two times at low temperature.
Abstract Electron spin qubits are becoming an important research direction in the field of quantum computing and information storage. However, the quantum decoherence has seriously hindered the development of this field. So far, few qubits exhibit long phase memory time (Tm), and even fewer qubits that can reach room temperature. Some reports show that the coherence times of radicals are generally long, so radicals may be the preferred spin carriers for qubits. Here, we demonstrate the qubit properties of a photogenerated radical (1 a) based on 2,4,6‐Tri(4‐pyridyl)‐1,3,5‐triazine (tpt, 1). More importantly, the photogenerated radical is a spin self‐diluting complex, which the dilution is generally used in the investigation of qubits to reduce the interference of environment on qubits in order to overcome the decoherence of qubits. It is surprised that radical tpt has a stable Tm=1.1 μs above 20 K, even keep it to room temperature. In addition, the tpt‐film prepared by the vacuum evaporation is significantly increase the T1 and Tm at low temperature.
item.content:encoded:
The reversible photogenerated radicals 2,4,6-Tri(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine (tpt) show a temperature-independent quantum coherence with T m=1.1 μs at 20–300 K and the T m of tpt-film increased by two times at low temperature.


Abstract

Electron spin qubits are becoming an important research direction in the field of quantum computing and information storage. However, the quantum decoherence has seriously hindered the development of this field. So far, few qubits exhibit long phase memory time (T m), and even fewer qubits that can reach room temperature. Some reports show that the coherence times of radicals are generally long, so radicals may be the preferred spin carriers for qubits. Here, we demonstrate the qubit properties of a photogenerated radical (1 a) based on 2,4,6-Tri(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine (tpt, 1). More importantly, the photogenerated radical is a spin self-diluting complex, which the dilution is generally used in the investigation of qubits to reduce the interference of environment on qubits in order to overcome the decoherence of qubits. It is surprised that radical tpt has a stable T m=1.1 μs above 20 K, even keep it to room temperature. In addition, the tpt-film prepared by the vacuum evaporation is significantly increase the T 1 and T m at low temperature.
item.dc:creator: Ming‐Hui Cui, Yi‐Ming Lu, Jia Wang, Zhongwen Ouyang, Zhenxing Wang, Chongyun Shao, You Song
item.dc:title: Room‐Temperature Quantum Coherence of Reversible Photo‐Generated Radical and its Film

item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: Photoinduced Metal‐Free Decarboxylative Fluoroalkylation of Alkenes for the Synthesis of N‐Arylbutanamides and Oxindoles
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A new photoinduced decarboxylative difluoroalkylation‐carbocyclization reaction of alkenes for the divergent construction of CF2‐containing oxindoles and N‐arylbutanamides was established. This photocatalysis reaction features simple conditions, transition metal photocatalysts free.
Abstract The visible light‐induced decarboxylative cascade reaction of fluoroalkyl carboxylic acids has been achieved for the efficient synthesis of fluorinated compounds. However, most of the transformations rely on noble iridium metal complex. Herein, a visible light‐induced metal‐free decarboxylative cascade reaction of fluoroalkyl carboxylic acids has been realized. This protocol features simple operation, transition metal free, and good functional group tolerance.
item.content:encoded:
A new photoinduced decarboxylative difluoroalkylation-carbocyclization reaction of alkenes for the divergent construction of CF2-containing oxindoles and N-arylbutanamides was established. This photocatalysis reaction features simple conditions, transition metal photocatalysts free.


Abstract

The visible light-induced decarboxylative cascade reaction of fluoroalkyl carboxylic acids has been achieved for the efficient synthesis of fluorinated compounds. However, most of the transformations rely on noble iridium metal complex. Herein, a visible light-induced metal-free decarboxylative cascade reaction of fluoroalkyl carboxylic acids has been realized. This protocol features simple operation, transition metal free, and good functional group tolerance.
item.dc:creator: Yi‐Gang Ji, Zhuo‐Hong Li, Yu‐Qing Yang, Xiaohu Yang, Wen‐Chao Yang
item.dc:title: Photoinduced Metal‐Free Decarboxylative Fluoroalkylation of Alkenes for the Synthesis of N‐Arylbutanamides and Oxindoles

item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: A Comparative Study of a High‐Pressure Polymorph of I2O5 and its Ambient‐Pressure Modification
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
We present the high‐pressure/high‐temperature synthesis, crystal structure determination, and characterization of a new high‐pressure modification of I2O5. The phase transition between the ambient‐ and high‐pressure polymorph has been studied by temperature‐dependent X‐ray powder diffraction and volume‐dependent DFT calculations.
Abstract A hitherto unknown modification of I2O5 was obtained from high‐pressure/high‐temperature syntheses in a Walker‐type multianvil device at 8 GPa and 250 °C. HP‐I2O5 crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system with space group P21/c (no. 14) with the unit cell parameters a=12.0612(3) Å, b=4.8613(2) Å, c=6.9585(2) Å, β=100.10(1)° (at 173 K), and four formula units per cell. The single‐crystal structure data are accompanied by powder X‐ray diffraction data at ambient and elevated temperatures. Furthermore, DFT calculations were carried out to investigate the phase transition between the ambient‐pressure polymorph NP‐I2O5 to the newly synthesized high‐pressure phase.
item.content:encoded:
We present the high-pressure/high-temperature synthesis, crystal structure determination, and characterization of a new high-pressure modification of I2O5. The phase transition between the ambient- and high-pressure polymorph has been studied by temperature-dependent X-ray powder diffraction and volume-dependent DFT calculations.


Abstract

A hitherto unknown modification of I2O5 was obtained from high-pressure/high-temperature syntheses in a Walker-type multianvil device at 8 GPa and 250 °C. HP-I2O5 crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system with space group P21/c (no. 14) with the unit cell parameters a=12.0612(3) Å, b=4.8613(2) Å, c=6.9585(2) Å, β=100.10(1)° (at 173 K), and four formula units per cell. The single-crystal structure data are accompanied by powder X-ray diffraction data at ambient and elevated temperatures. Furthermore, DFT calculations were carried out to investigate the phase transition between the ambient-pressure polymorph NP-I2O5 to the newly synthesized high-pressure phase.
item.dc:creator: Tobias A. Teichtmeister, Dirk Johrendt, Alexander Hugo Bernhart, Gunter Heymann, Hubert Huppertz
item.dc:title: A Comparative Study of a High‐Pressure Polymorph of I2O5 and its Ambient‐Pressure Modification

item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: Janus Reactivity of Crownphyrinoids: Alkali‐ vs. Transition Metal‐Mediated Transformations of Crown Ether‐Porphyrin Hybrids
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
The dual‐nature cavities of crownphyrinoids enable reactivity at distinct porphyrinoid‐ or crown ether part of the macrocyclic ligand. Depending on the metal and oxidation level of the macrocycle, they bind cations, yielding monomeric, dimeric, or accordion‐like complexes. The use of a crownphyrin capable of incorporating two metal centres allowed for obtaining heterobinuclear complexes wherein the macrocycle demonstrated the Janus reactivity.
Abstract Crownphyrinogens and crownphyrins constitute a group of macrocycles that combine the structural facets of porphyrinoids and crown ethers. The dual‐nature cavity embedded in their molecules enables reactivity involving two structurally distinct parts of the macrocyclic ligand. Upon Ni(II) and Pd(II) insertion, coordination compounds are produced wherein the metal is incorporated into the porphyrinoid‐like pocket, resulting in monomeric or accordion‐like dimeric products, depending on the oxidation level of the macrocycle and metal cation. The reactions with Na(I) and K(I) resulted in the formation of complexes where only the crown ether segment of the molecule is involved in metal binding, yielding remarkable dimeric species. The exploitation of a crownphyrin large enough to accommodate two metal cations allowed the synthesis of an alkali/transition metal binuclear complexes wherein the macrocycle demonstrated the Janus reactivity with one cavity acting as a porphyrinoid and the other mimicking the crown ether.
item.content:encoded:
The dual-nature cavities of crownphyrinoids enable reactivity at distinct porphyrinoid- or crown ether part of the macrocyclic ligand. Depending on the metal and oxidation level of the macrocycle, they bind cations, yielding monomeric, dimeric, or accordion-like complexes. The use of a crownphyrin capable of incorporating two metal centres allowed for obtaining heterobinuclear complexes wherein the macrocycle demonstrated the Janus reactivity.


Abstract

Crownphyrinogens and crownphyrins constitute a group of macrocycles that combine the structural facets of porphyrinoids and crown ethers. The dual-nature cavity embedded in their molecules enables reactivity involving two structurally distinct parts of the macrocyclic ligand. Upon Ni(II) and Pd(II) insertion, coordination compounds are produced wherein the metal is incorporated into the porphyrinoid-like pocket, resulting in monomeric or accordion-like dimeric products, depending on the oxidation level of the macrocycle and metal cation. The reactions with Na(I) and K(I) resulted in the formation of complexes where only the crown ether segment of the molecule is involved in metal binding, yielding remarkable dimeric species. The exploitation of a crownphyrin large enough to accommodate two metal cations allowed the synthesis of an alkali/transition metal binuclear complexes wherein the macrocycle demonstrated the Janus reactivity with one cavity acting as a porphyrinoid and the other mimicking the crown ether.
item.dc:creator: Maksym Matviyishyn, Krzysztof A. Konieczny, Bartosz Trzaskowski, Bartosz Szyszko
item.dc:title: Janus Reactivity of Crownphyrinoids: Alkali‐ vs. Transition Metal‐Mediated Transformations of Crown Ether‐Porphyrin Hybrids

item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: Consequences of the Pb−S Bond Formation for Lead Halide Perovskites
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Sulfur radical used instead of the A cation in lead halide perovskites builds the Pb−S covalent bond, confirmed by the quantum theory of atoms in molecules and non‐covalent interactions index. This bond triggers a phase transition to stable non‐perovskite structure that hosts multiexcitons obeying the exciton‐fission preconditions, according to an analysis derived from the Bethe–Salpeter equation.
Abstract Lead halide perovskites are structurally not stable due to their ionic bonds. Using sulfur agents in the crystal growth improves the stability and performance of the photovoltaic and light‐emitting devices. In this theoretical work, we use a small toy S‐radical in place of A cation in the bulk of lead iodide perovskite, and highlight the significance of the Pb−S covalent‐double‐bond formation for: the charge redistribution on the neighboring bonds that also turn to be covalent, phase transformation to a stable non‐perovskite structure, and superior optoelectronic properties. The chemical analysis was performed with the Quantum Theory of Atoms In Molecules (QTAIM) and Non‐Covalent Interactions (NCI) index. Excitonic properties were obtained from the solution of ab initio Bethe–Salpeter equation. Presence of the spin‐orbit coupling triggers an interplay between the Frenkel and charge‐transfer multiexcitons, switching between the photovoltaic and laser applications. Multiexcitons obey the exciton‐fission preconditions.
item.content:encoded:
Sulfur radical used instead of the A cation in lead halide perovskites builds the Pb−S covalent bond, confirmed by the quantum theory of atoms in molecules and non-covalent interactions index. This bond triggers a phase transition to stable non-perovskite structure that hosts multiexcitons obeying the exciton-fission preconditions, according to an analysis derived from the Bethe–Salpeter equation.


Abstract

Lead halide perovskites are structurally not stable due to their ionic bonds. Using sulfur agents in the crystal growth improves the stability and performance of the photovoltaic and light-emitting devices. In this theoretical work, we use a small toy S-radical in place of A cation in the bulk of lead iodide perovskite, and highlight the significance of the Pb−S covalent-double-bond formation for: the charge redistribution on the neighboring bonds that also turn to be covalent, phase transformation to a stable non-perovskite structure, and superior optoelectronic properties. The chemical analysis was performed with the Quantum Theory of Atoms In Molecules (QTAIM) and Non-Covalent Interactions (NCI) index. Excitonic properties were obtained from the solution of ab initio Bethe–Salpeter equation. Presence of the spin-orbit coupling triggers an interplay between the Frenkel and charge-transfer multiexcitons, switching between the photovoltaic and laser applications. Multiexcitons obey the exciton-fission preconditions.
item.dc:creator: Małgorzata Wierzbowska, Kamil Wojtkowiak, Alicja Mikłas, Aneta Jezierska
item.dc:title: Consequences of the Pb−S Bond Formation for Lead Halide Perovskites

item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: Synthesis of 4‐(Phenylamino)quinazoline‐2(1H)‐thiones Using Green Solvents
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Environmentally friendly process for synthesizing heterocyclic molecules of therapeutic interest with the quinazoline‐2(1H)‐thione core structure, using bio‐based recyclable solvents.
Abstract Given the importance of quinazolines and quinazolinethiones in therapeutic and Food and Drug Administration (FDA)‐approved molecules, we thought interesting to consider their synthesis in green solvents. We have shown that obtain 4‐(arylamino)quinazoline‐2‐(1H)‐thiones and 4‐(arylamino)pteridine‐2‐(1H)‐thiones analogues was efficient in green solvents derived from biomass, especially eucalyptol. Although reaction times are somewhat long to achieve good yields, the products were obtained by simple filtration. This considerably limited the loss of atoms due to the use of large quantities of solvents for purification on silica gel columns, and makes our route a sustainable one.
item.content:encoded:
Environmentally friendly process for synthesizing heterocyclic molecules of therapeutic interest with the quinazoline-2(1H)-thione core structure, using bio-based recyclable solvents.


Abstract

Given the importance of quinazolines and quinazolinethiones in therapeutic and Food and Drug Administration (FDA)-approved molecules, we thought interesting to consider their synthesis in green solvents. We have shown that obtain 4-(arylamino)quinazoline-2-(1H)-thiones and 4-(arylamino)pteridine-2-(1H)-thiones analogues was efficient in green solvents derived from biomass, especially eucalyptol. Although reaction times are somewhat long to achieve good yields, the products were obtained by simple filtration. This considerably limited the loss of atoms due to the use of large quantities of solvents for purification on silica gel columns, and makes our route a sustainable one.
item.dc:creator: Gatien Messire, Claudie Adolf, Sabine Berteina‐Raboin
item.dc:title: Synthesis of 4‐(Phenylamino)quinazoline‐2(1H)‐thiones Using Green Solvents

item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: Achieving Regioselectivity for Remote C−H Activation by Substructure Conformations: an Approach of Paralogous Cytochrome P450 Enzymes
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Controlling regioselectivity in C−H activation is challenging, particularly for complex substrates. Cytochrome P450 monooxygenases (CYPs) offer a solution by modulating distance and geometry between the reaction center and target site. Comparative studies on homologous CYPs, such as IkaD and CftA, reveal that distinct substructure conformations can influence regioselectivity and have implications for CYP engineering.
Abstract For advanced synthetic intermediates or natural products with multiple unactivated and energetically similar C(sp3)−H bonds, controlling regioselectivity for the C−H activation is particularly challenging. The use of cytochrome P450 enzymes (CYPs) is a promising solution to the ‘regioelectivity’ challenge in remote C−H activation. Notably, CYPs and organic catalysts share a fundamental principle: they strive to control the distance and geometry between the metal reaction center and the target C−H site. Most structural analyses of the regioselectivity of CYPs are limited to the active pocket, particularly when explaining why regioselectivity could be altered by enzyme engineering through mutagenesis. However, the substructures responsible for forming the active pocket in CYPs are well known to display complex dynamic changes and substrate‐induced plasticity. In this context, we highlight a comparative study of the recently reported paralogous CYPs, IkaD and CftA, which achieve different regioselectivity towards the same substrate ikarugamycin by distinct substructure conformations. We propose that substructural conformation‐controlled regioselectivity might also be present in CYPs of other natural product biosynthesis pathways, which should be considered when engineering CYPs for regioselective modifications.
item.content:encoded:
Controlling regioselectivity in C−H activation is challenging, particularly for complex substrates. Cytochrome P450 monooxygenases (CYPs) offer a solution by modulating distance and geometry between the reaction center and target site. Comparative studies on homologous CYPs, such as IkaD and CftA, reveal that distinct substructure conformations can influence regioselectivity and have implications for CYP engineering.


Abstract

For advanced synthetic intermediates or natural products with multiple unactivated and energetically similar C(sp3)−H bonds, controlling regioselectivity for the C−H activation is particularly challenging. The use of cytochrome P450 enzymes (CYPs) is a promising solution to the ‘regioelectivity’ challenge in remote C−H activation. Notably, CYPs and organic catalysts share a fundamental principle: they strive to control the distance and geometry between the metal reaction center and the target C−H site. Most structural analyses of the regioselectivity of CYPs are limited to the active pocket, particularly when explaining why regioselectivity could be altered by enzyme engineering through mutagenesis. However, the substructures responsible for forming the active pocket in CYPs are well known to display complex dynamic changes and substrate-induced plasticity. In this context, we highlight a comparative study of the recently reported paralogous CYPs, IkaD and CftA, which achieve different regioselectivity towards the same substrate ikarugamycin by distinct substructure conformations. We propose that substructural conformation-controlled regioselectivity might also be present in CYPs of other natural product biosynthesis pathways, which should be considered when engineering CYPs for regioselective modifications.
item.dc:creator: Liping Zhang, Peng Jiang, Hongbo Jin, Changsheng Zhang
item.dc:title: Achieving Regioselectivity for Remote C−H Activation by Substructure Conformations: an Approach of Paralogous Cytochrome P450 Enzymes

item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: Interdependent Dynamic Nitroaldol and Boronic Ester Reactions for Complex Dynamers of Different Topologies
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Dynamic systems based on interdependent nitroaldol and boronate reactions have been demonstrated. Bifunctional building blocks led to mainchain nitroaldol‐boronate dynamers as well as multi‐dynamic networks with distinct topologies. The features of the dynamers were dependent on the boronic acid configuration.
Abstract Complex dynamic systems displaying interdependency between nitroaldol and boronic ester reactions have been demonstrated. Nitroalkane‐1,3‐diols, generated by the nitroaldol reaction, were susceptible to ester formation with different boronic acids in aprotic solvents, whereas hydrolysis of the esters occurred in the presence of water. The boronic ester formation led to significant stabilization of the nitroaldol adducts under basic conditions. The use of bifunctional building blocks was furthermore established, allowing for main chain nitroaldol‐boronate dynamers as well as complex network dynamers with distinct topologies. The shape and rigidity of the resulting dynamers showed an apparent dependency on the configuration of the boronic acids.
item.content:encoded:
Dynamic systems based on interdependent nitroaldol and boronate reactions have been demonstrated. Bifunctional building blocks led to mainchain nitroaldol-boronate dynamers as well as multi-dynamic networks with distinct topologies. The features of the dynamers were dependent on the boronic acid configuration.


Abstract

Complex dynamic systems displaying interdependency between nitroaldol and boronic ester reactions have been demonstrated. Nitroalkane-1,3-diols, generated by the nitroaldol reaction, were susceptible to ester formation with different boronic acids in aprotic solvents, whereas hydrolysis of the esters occurred in the presence of water. The boronic ester formation led to significant stabilization of the nitroaldol adducts under basic conditions. The use of bifunctional building blocks was furthermore established, allowing for main chain nitroaldol-boronate dynamers as well as complex network dynamers with distinct topologies. The shape and rigidity of the resulting dynamers showed an apparent dependency on the configuration of the boronic acids.

item.dc:title: Interdependent Dynamic Nitroaldol and Boronic Ester Reactions for Complex Dynamers of Different Topologies

item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: Heterometallic [2]Catenane‐Crosslinked Supramolecular Networks with Improved Antibacterial Activity
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: The construction of supramolecular networks with novel crosslinks is of great significance in expanding their chemical structures and exploring their advanced functions. Herein, we prepare a type of [2]catenane‐cored supramolecular networks based on the crosslinking of polyethylene glycol (PEG) using a heterometallic [2]catenane unit. By adjusting the molecular weight of PEG, the solubility of the networks can be tuned and gels are formed using low molecular weight PEG. The introduction of heterometallic [2]catenane offers the networks good antibacterial properties owing to the synergistic antimicrobial activity of Pt(II) and Cu(I) ions in the [2]catenane. This study provides a simple and efficient strategy for constructing supramolecular networks with topological crosslinks as antibacterial materials, which will promote the structural design and biological applications of supramolecular networks.

By adjusting the molecular weight of PEG, the solubility of the networks can be tuned and gels are formed using low molecular weight PEG. The introduction of heterometallic [2]catenane offers the networks good antibacterial properties owing to the synergistic antimicrobial activity of Pt(II) and Cu(I) ions in the [2]catenane. This study provides a simple and efficient strategy for constructing supramolecular networks with topological crosslinks as antibacterial materials, which will promote the structural design and biological applications of supramolecular networks.
